page.title: 10The Coastal Footpath in July
page.content: On this stretch from Samphire Island to Hell's Mouth, it is possible to see many species of animal and plant life. Thyme, foxgloves, heather, wild roses and wild orchids can all be found. Butterflies fly over the cliff top. Birds include nesting gulls and other sea birds. On the cultivated pasture close to the cliff edge are numerous skylarks. Caves are seen at the foot of the cliffs and the 200 foot drop at Hells Mouth is a favourite stopping place for tourists. Paths are worn smooth by walkers or overgrown with dense scrub of heather or gorse. Some sections are steep and dangerous, others open, providing car parks for those who wish to walk only a short distance.
